title: What riot has done to their game, and the fact that it leads to lower sales.
body:
Fact is a lot of players aren't happy with your game, and honestly a lot of players stop buying skins when they are fed up with your bullshit.

And i love this skin showing tab, because it shows just how little i have given to the game in the past year.

In the past year, i have acquired 9 skins, out of those, i bought 1.

And it's not like i don't buy skins before the more recent stuff, i have 141 skins, you guys really need to pull this shit out of the dumpster, because lets face it, your not getting any new players, so your player-base is your only way to get more money, and you'll slowly lose more and more money as you piss off more and more people.

Exactly.  Consumers got sick of EAS bullshit and walked away from the game.

Obviously, emulating ea is a profit seeking move from riot but after being the best ftp model of any game for almost a decade they  copied the practices of the most hated gaming company on the globe.

That's what happens when you put accountants in charge of a company formerly headed by gamers.

I fear riot are shooting themselves in the foot by adopting an in game currency designed to milk their players like this.

I think you make a good point about new players declining vs treating existing players poorly. The barriers to entry in this game are high because of the enormous champ pool to learn. Something like hots sets itself apart by having short matches on easy to master champs.

I wonder what new player stats are like. I did notice that revenue in 2013 was 2bn but 2015 was only 1.6bn. Still bloody impressive earner but almost a 25% dip in revenue over 2 years. Pretty telling.

I mean the main stat that matters to riot is how many "whales" are constantly paying for their game.

Fact is, that number is decreasing, and it's not going to rise back up, unless they can tempt them back by not running like shit.

League has hit the highest point it ever is going to for money, and unless they better the New Player Experience, it's a downhill slope from here.

I was a smaller whale. Not irrational spending of life savings, but happy to drop $50-$100 per year on skins to see the game evolve and support it.

Will be spending money on other things now.  This direction is taking the absolute piss.

Thats possibly why they've gone down the BE route too - closer to loot box arrangements which require a bigger spend to get less. Suspect the strategy is to milk the remaining population as much as possible before they go and all that remain are the hard core fans who are too invested in the game to play anything else.
I mean admittedly i was a bit of a whale, but i've just flat out stopped for a year and a bit now, the last MAJOR purchase i made was elementalist lux.

The lower population base and the jacking up of loot box and pay to play mechanisms follows a model:

https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/7igijd/i_was_a_game_designer_at_a_freetoplay_game/

> I'd say that, on average, pay-to-win tendencies increase as a game's popularity goes down over time. When the game first starts out, balance and preserving the player ecosystem is everything.
> As the game gets older, people start moving onto the next big thing, but a core sticks around. There's less of them, but they tend to spend more, on average.
> As the game reaches it's final stage (sometimes called Farm Stage), a very small team is in charge of keeping the game on life support. They may love the game, but their development resources are tiny. The only thing they can do is fiddle with numbers. If you can't get your remaining players excited with new art, levels, or mechanics, what do you turn to?
